articles.author: Bence SzabÃ³
articles.description:
I recently created a brick wall pattern as part of my #PetitePatterns series, a challenge where I create organic-looking patterns or textures in SVG within 560 bytes (or approximately the size of two tweets). To fit this constraint, I have â€¦
Optimizing SVG Patterns to Their Smallest Size originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Optimizing SVG Patterns to Their Smallest Size

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Hey hey!
Iâ€™ve got a big announcement to make here. (Whereâ€™s my gong? I feel like this really needs a good gong hit.)
CSS-Tricks, this very website youâ€™re looking at, has been acquired by DigitalOcean!
You can hear â€¦
CSS-Tricks is joining DigitalOcean! originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS-Tricks is joining DigitalOcean!

articles.author: Patrick Brosset
articles.description:
I want to introduce you to a new, experimental form control called <selectmenu>. Weâ€™ll get deep into it, including how much easier it is to style than a traditional <select> element. But first, letâ€™s fill in some context â€¦
Say Hello to selectmenu, a Fully Style-able select Element originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Say Hello to selectmenu, a Fully Style-able select Element

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
(This is a sponsored post.)
What would your business be like if you sold memberships? It might be more than fun to think about, in fact, it might just be transformative. With membership, would you include little add-ons or â€¦
Build Membership Businesses with Memberful originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Build Membership Businesses with Memberful

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
I have a handful of good links to articles about performance that are burning a hole in my bookmarks folder, and wanna drop them here to share.
The new WebPageTest website design
From fonts to SVG: an icon migration strategy
â€¦
7 Fresh Links on Performance For March 2022 originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: 7 Fresh Links on Performance For March 2022

articles.author: Silvestar BistroviÄ‡
articles.description:
â€œRaise the curtainsâ€ is what I call an effect where the background goes from dark to light on scroll, and the content on top also goes from light to dark while in a sticky position.
Hereâ€™s an example where I â€¦
How to Make a â€œRaise the Curtainsâ€ Effect in CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: How to Make a â€œRaise the Curtainsâ€ Effect in CSS

articles.author: Patrick Brosset
articles.description:
Styling ranges of text in software is a very useful thing to be able to do. Thankfully, we have the CSS Custom Highlight API to look forward to because it represents the future of styling text ranges on the web.â€¦
CSS Custom Highlight API: The Future of Highlighting Text Ranges on the Web originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Custom Highlight API: The Future of Highlighting Text Ranges on the Web

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Ahmad Shadeed covers the CSS fit-content sizing keyword. Itâ€™s useful! It just doesnâ€™t come up super often. I find myself using min-content a lot more, like when setting up the height of a grid-template-row.
The fit-content keyword is actually â€¦
Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Ahmad Shadeed: Use Cases For CSS fit-content

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
I enjoy articles like Hartley Charltonâ€™s â€œMicrosoft Edge Looks Set to Overtake Safari as Worldâ€™s Second Most Popular Desktop Browser.â€ Itâ€™s juicy! We know these massive players in the browser market care very much about their market share, so when â€¦
IE Down, Edge Upâ€¦ Global Browser Usage Stats Are for Cocktail Parties and Conference Slides originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: IE Down, Edge Upâ€¦ Global Browser Usage Stats Are for Cocktail Parties and Conference Slides

articles.author: John Rhea
articles.description:
Weâ€™ve discussed a lot about the internals of using CSS in this ongoing series on web components, but there are a few special pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes that, like good friends, willingly smell your possibly halitotic breath before you go â€¦
Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Web Component Pseudo-Classes and Pseudo-Elements are Easier Than You Think

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
A fun deep dive from Zach. Do you have an opinion on which you should use?
1) https://website.com/foo/
2) https://websites.com/foo
The first option has a â€œtrailing slash.â€ The second does not.
Iâ€™ve always preferred this thinking: you use a trailing â€¦
Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled? originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Trailing Slashes on URLs: Contentious or Settled?

articles.author: Å ime Vidas
articles.description:
In my recent article about CSS underline bugs in Chrome, I discussed text-decoration-thickness and text-underline-offset, two relatively new and widely-supported CSS properties that give us more control over the styling of underlines.
Let me demonstrate the usefulness of â€¦
When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: When to Avoid the text-decoration Shorthand Property

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
If youâ€™re looking for a primer on CSS specificity, weâ€™ve got that. And if youâ€™re trying to get ahead of the game, you should be aware of CSS Cascade Layers as well.
One of the ways to help get â€¦
Manuel Matuzovicâ€™s CSS Specificity Demo originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Manuel Matuzovicâ€™s CSS Specificity Demo

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Nic Chan:
[â€¦] theÂ will-changeÂ property landed in major browsers in August 2015, and Iâ€™ve been on the lookout for when to use it ever since. It might seem self-evident to apply it to commonly animated properties such 
â€¦
My white whale: A use case for will-change originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: My white whale: A use case for will-change

articles.author: Anand Chowdhary
articles.description:
For the past few weeks, Iâ€™ve been hiring for a senior full-stack JavaScript engineer at my rental furniture company, Pabio. Since weâ€™re a remote team, we conduct our interviews on Zoom, and Iâ€™ve observed that some developers are not â€¦
Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitterâ€™s Source Code to Me originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitterâ€™s Source Code to Me

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine â€” For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joseph Zimmerman)
articles.description: Building on a previous article on How to Build a Drag-and-Drop File Uploader, weâ€™ll be adding some new features, but more importantly (maybe), weâ€™ll be learning how to build it in Vue 3 and learn some best practices for Vue along the way.
articles.title: How To Make A Drag-and-Drop File Uploader With Vue.js 3

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: This fresh new design trend has been picking up steam with the rising popularity of colorful inflated 3D graphics in web illustrations and with the latest Virtual Reality projects like â€œHorizon Worldsâ€. Letâ€™s see if there is room for Claymorphism on the UI, and how we can create this effect with CSS.
articles.title: Claymorphism: Will It Stick Around?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Tom Hastjarjanto)
articles.description: Looking for ways to create a smooth CI/CD flow for your software? In this article, Tom Hastjarjanto shares some useful concepts that can be combined with GitHub Actions and NPM packages. With this setup, you will be able to release multiple times per hour with a fully documented trace managed by Git.
articles.title: Improving The CI/CD Flow For Your Application

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sona Dabaghyan)
articles.description: Standing out among the millions of mobile apps can be challenging, but proper marketing can give you that crucial edge. This piece shares how to start your mobile app marketing strategy and improve it as you go while keeping up with the latest trends in the market.
articles.title: A Complete Guide To Mobile App Marketing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vivek Maskara)
articles.description: In this article, Vivek Maskara introduces Amazon Web Servicesâ€™ (AWS) Cloud Development Kit (CDK) which is increasingly becoming a popular tool for managing AWS-based infrastructure. Weâ€™ll take a closer look into CDK concepts, and then how to use the AWS CDK toolkit to deploy a sample application to an AWS account.
articles.title: An Introduction To AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jhey Tompkins)
articles.description: What started as a case study turned into a guide to visualizing audio with JavaScript. Although the output demos are in React, Jhey Tompkins isnâ€™t going to dwell on the React side of things too much. The underlying techniques work with or without React.
articles.title: A Guide To Audio Visualization With JavaScript And GSAP (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Barry Pollard)
articles.description: Using signals to deliver less, or different, content is a form of progressive enhancement (or graceful degradation depending on how you look at it), whereby extraneous content is only loaded when necessary, but the core functionality of the website still works. In this article, weâ€™ll look at some of the signals that can be used for this.
articles.title: Performance Signals For Customizing Website UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: If users cannot find the answers to their questions or are not exposed to critical messaging, they will not act, and your website will fail. To prevent that from happening, you need an effective information architecture. In this article, Paul Boag provides you with a process to ensure you have precisely that.
articles.title: How To Create An Information Architecture That Is Easy To Use

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stephanie Stimac)
articles.description: Dual-screen devices are just the next evolution in responsive design. If you have a PWA or website, the APIs available make integrating into your existing code base seamless. This article explains why itâ€™s an exciting time for layout on the web, and how dual screens provide an opportunity to get even more creative.
articles.title: Building Web Layouts For Dual-Screen And Foldable Devices

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jhey Tompkins)
articles.description: What started as a case study turned into a guide to visualizing audio with JavaScript. Although the output demos are in React, Jhey Tompkins isnâ€™t going to dwell on the React side of things too much. The underlying techniques work with or without React.
articles.title: A Guide To Audio Visualization With JavaScript And GSAP (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: 2022 is shaping up to be a pretty great year for CSS, with a plethora of new features on the horizon. Some are already starting to land in browsers, others are likely to gain widespread browser support in 2022, while for one or two the process may be a little longer. In this article weâ€™ll take a look at a few of them.
articles.title: New CSS Features In 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: As a design community, we all canâ€™t be silent in these times. We need to be united in our fight against the war, for democracy, for those dreams that children are entitled to have when they are growing up. Itâ€™s our obligation to help as much as we can. **We are donating all proceeds** from "Interface Design Checklists" PDF to support Ukraine.
articles.title: We All Are Ukraine ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Following our monthly tradition, artists and designers from across the globe challenged their creative skills and designed desktop wallpapers to welcome March. They come in versions with and without a calendar and can be downloaded for free.
articles.title: March For Equality (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ãtila Fassina)
articles.description: Maintaining a design system is a lot of work. In this article, Atila Fassina shares his lessons learned and how a platform such as Backlight can help put together a series of tools to speed up your architecture setup.
articles.title: A Recipe For A Good Design System

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ãtila Fassina)
articles.description: Web Vitals are the new gold standard in performance due to their direct correlation with the userâ€™s experience. In this article, youâ€™ll learn what monitoring can do and how RayGun can help you sustain performance maintenance while scaling your app.
articles.title: How To Benchmark And Improve Web Vitals With Real User Metrics

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: If we want our WordPress plugins to offer a settings page that is fully powered by blocks, how can we do it? Since *Full Site Editing* doesnâ€™t support this feature yet, we need to code a custom solution. In this article, we will learn how we can do it.
articles.title: Using The WordPress Editor And CPTs To Configure Plugins

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ilya Medvedev)
articles.description: How do text typing and editing work on the web? Although this process might seem straightforward, there is a lot of technical nuance behind its apparent simplicity. This article looks at how typing on the web works.
articles.title: How To Develop A Text Editor For The Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, weâ€™re talking about Responsible JavaScript. What does it mean for code to be responsible, and how should we approach projects differently? Drew McLellan talks to expert Jeremy Wagner to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 45 With Jeremy Wagner: What Is Responsible JavaScript?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: You donâ€™t need to be a full DevOps engineer if you want to introduce a testing build routine. With the help of some testing frameworks and GitHub actions, Ramona Schwering gives a short kick-off to help you get on the right track.
articles.title: Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When crafting the logic in your code, you may want to execute different commands depending on the similarities or differences between two or more strings.  In this article, we'll see various operators that can help us check if strings are equal or not. If two strings are equal, the
articles.title: Python Compare Strings â€“ How to Check for String Equality

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: At the start of your web development journey, you will often hear about the frontend and the backend parts of an application. But what do these terms mean exactly? In this article, you will learn about the differences between the two by examining the frontend and backend separately. Here is
articles.title: Frontend VS Backend â€“ What's the Difference?

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When creating a program, you may need to get numerical input from users and perform various mathematical operations on the value.  Similarly, there are cases where you might want to perform mathematical operations on string values.  In both cases, the values returned are strings so we cannot perform
articles.title: Python String to Int â€“ Convert a String Example

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: WebGPU is the next-generation graphics API and future web standard for graphics and compute, aiming to provide modern 3D graphics and computation capabilities with the GPU acceleration. We just published a WebGPU course on the freeCodeCmap.org YouTube channel.  Dr. Jack Xu developed this course. Dr. Xu has over 25
articles.title: Learn WebGPU â€“ A next-generation graphics API for the web

articles.author: Zaira Hira
articles.description: Searching for files is relatively easy when you are using a GUI. But in certain environments like GUI-less servers, you need to search for files using the command line.  There is a powerful command in Linux that helps you search for files and folders called find. In this article,
articles.title: How to Search for Files from the Linux Command Line

articles.author: Slimane Aguersif
articles.description: In this article I'm going to discuss some use cases of REM (Root EM) in CSS.  I will begin with some background knowledge about CSS properties and values, which I think is necessary. Then I'll discuss the differences between absolute length values and relative ones. REM is a relative
articles.title: CSS REM â€“ What is REM in CSS?

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: While running a Python program, there might be times when you'd like to delay the execution of the program for some seconds. The Python time module has a built-in function called time.sleep() with which you can delay the execution of a program. With the sleep() function, you can get more
articles.title: Python Sleep â€“ time.sleep() in Python

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: If you are looking for a web developer job it can be helpful to have a portfolio website. It can also be helpful to have projects you've created to show to potential employers. You can accomplish both tasks at once by creating your own portfolio website with HTML, CSS, &
articles.title: Create a Portfolio Website Using HTML, CSS, & JavaScript

articles.author: Ashutosh Krishna
articles.description: In this Python tutorial, we'll learn how to build a terminal application (CLI app) to manage our contact book.  We'll use Typer for building the CLI app, Rich for a colorized terminal output, and TinyDB for the database. Get your tools ready We'll be using a few external libraries
articles.title: How to Build a Contact Book Application in Python using Rich, Typer, and TinyDB

articles.author: GermÃ¡n Cocca
articles.description: In this article we'll talk about what debugging is, how to debug your code, and how you can get better at it. Table of contents  * How Debugging Started  * Why Should You Learn About Debugging?  * How to Debug Your Code  * How to Get
articles.title: What is Debugging? How to Debug Your Code for Beginners
